Mridul,

One thing to consider here is that if your nodes can be given co=
ordinates, then your problem looks like a CPPN:  You are basically asking f=
or (x1,y1,x2,y2) whether the two coordinates are connected.  That's essenti=
ally what a CPPN does.  So if you tried to train a CPPN to answer correctly=
 for your particular graph, then you'd be getting a CPPN encoding of that g=
raph.  The part I am a little fuzzy about is how that would help with a dif=
ferent such graph.  To the extent the two graphs overlap, it would work, bu=
t if they don't, I'm not sure how learning from the first graph would gener=
alize to the second.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mridul P <p_mridul@=
...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken,
> 
> The testing data is related to the same graph.=
 I believe that there is some 
> underlying geometry between the nodes in t=
he graph, and there should be some 
> regularities in the connectivity. Oth=
er researchers have applied HMMs, Naive 
> Bayes classifiers etc to solve t=
his problem with limited results.
> 
> Thanks for the heads up.
> 
> Regard=
s,
> Mridul.
> 
> 
>

> Mridul, where does the testing data (i.e. what you will test it on a=
fter 
> training is over) come from?  Is it from a different graph or the s=
ame graph?  
> The reason I ask is that it probably matters whether the nod=
es will be the same 
> nodes (i.e. because they are from the same graph) or=
 nodes from an entirely 
> different graph.
> 
> In general, it does sound =
like you could create an array of 9000 inputs and 
> highlight the ones tha=
t you are asking about.  The main question for HyperNEAT 
> is whether thos=
e 9000 inputs can be situated in a meaningful geometry?  For 
> example, is=
 it naturally 300x300?  Or maybe something else?  If there is a 
> geometry=
 to them, and if there are regularities in their connectivity, then in 
> p=
rinciple HyperNEAT might be a good choice for learning that pattern.
> 
> A=
lso, note that with 9000 inputs, there will generally be a computational co=
st 
> to activating the network.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 "p_mridul" <p_mridul@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> > 
> > I am working on a bioin=
formatics problem, but it's easier to talk about it in 
> >graph theory ter=
ms....
> > 
> > I have a graph with a large number of nodes (~9000), and ab=
out 3000 edges 
> >between the nodes... I am planning to feed this as train=
ing data, and then see 
> >if the resulting NN will predict the probability=
 of an edge given any 2 nodes.
> > 
> > I have questions of how to encode t=
he inputs... do I create an input array of 
> >9000 inputs and pass in the =
couple of 1's corresponding to the nodes, or do I 
> >choose 2 inputs & pas=
s in the node numbers?
> > 
> > Thanks,
> > Mridul.
> >
>
